body_html:
This implementation should match what numpy does. Numpy actually has the same floating point problem in arange, but this pr should make it so pytorch is consistent with that. An example of where numpy has this error as well:

this pr pytorch

>>> torch.arange(0.6, 0.9, 0.1)

 0.6000
 0.7000
 0.8000
 0.9000
[torch.FloatTensor of size 4]

numpy

>>> np.arange(0.6, 0.9, 0.1)
array([0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9])

this pr pytorch

 0.6000

 0.9000
[torch.FloatTensor of size 4]

numpy
>>> np.arange(0.6, 0.9, 0.1)
array([0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9])
body:
This implementation should match what numpy does. Numpy actually has the same floating point problem in arange, but this pr should make it so pytorch is consistent with that. An example of where numpy has this error as well:

this pr pytorch
```
>>> torch.arange(0.6, 0.9, 0.1)

 0.6000
 0.7000
 0.8000
 0.9000
[torch.FloatTensor of size 4]
```

numpy
```
>>> np.arange(0.6, 0.9, 0.1)
array([0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9])
```
